      • getIsApplet

        public static boolean getIsApplet()
        return the static member indicating whether this is a application or applet. This static member controls other Util about whether certain thing can be done. For instance, Util.prt will put output in a SESSION.OUT file if its an application, but it cannot do this as an applet because file access is not allowed by applets via the sandbox.
        Returns:
        The current state of isApplet variable;

      • lptText

        public static void lptText(java.lang.String filename)
        send txt to the locally attached printer. This only make sense in a application. The lpt unit is opened automatically
        Parameters:
        filename - This file is read and formatted for output on a printer

                         java.lang.String txt)

        Parameters:

        txt - Some text to add to class information

      • prt

        public static void prt(java.io.PrintStream out,
                       java.lang.String txt)
        prt takes the input text and prints it out. It might go into the MSDOS window or to the SESSION.OUT file depending on the state of the debug flag. The "main" should decide on debug or not, set the flag and then all of the output will be available on the window or in the file. The file is really useful when something does not work because the user can e-mail it to us and a full debug listing is available for postmortem
        Parameters:
        out - The output PrintStream to send output,
        txt - The output text

      • prta

        public static void prta(java.io.PrintStream out,
                        java.lang.String txt)
        prta adds time stamp to output of prt(). takes the input text and prints it out. It might go into the MSDOS window or to the SESSION.OUT file depending on the state of the debug flag. The "main" should decide on debug or not, set the flag and then all of the output will be available on the window or in the file. The file is really useful when something does not work because the user can e-mail it to us and a full debug listing is available for postmortem
        Parameters:
        out - The output PrintStream to send output,
        txt - The output text

      • printResultSetMetaData

        public static void printResultSetMetaData(java.sql.ResultSet rs)
        This routine dumps the meta data and the current values from a ResultSet. Note: the values will always return NULL if the RS is on the insertRow, even if the insertRow columns have been updated
        Parameters:
        rs - The resultset to print

      • clearAllColumns

        public static void clearAllColumns(java.sql.ResultSet rs)
        Clear all of the fields in a ResultSet. Used the by the New record objects to insure everything is cleared for an InsertRow so the dumb thing will actually insert something! This uses the Result set meta data to get the desciptions and types of the columns
        Parameters:
        rs - The resultset to clear.

      • SQLErrorPrint

        public static void SQLErrorPrint(java.sql.SQLException E,
                                 java.lang.String msg)
        given and SQLException and local message string, dump the exception and system state at the time of the exception. This routine should be called by all "catch(SQLException) clauses to implement standard reporting.
        Parameters:
        E - The esction
        msg - The user supplied text to add

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(java.lang.String s)
        Escape a string for use in an SQL query. The string is returned enclosed in single quotes with any dangerous characters escaped. This is modeled after escape_string_for_mysql from the MySQL API. Beware that the characters '%' and '_' are not escaped. They do not have special meaning except in LIKE clauses.
        Parameters:
        s - The string to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(int i)
        Escape an int for use in an SQL query.
        Parameters:
        i - The int to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(long l)
        Escape a long for use in an SQL query.
        Parameters:
        l - The long to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(java.sql.Date d)
        Escape a Date for use in an SQL query. The string returned is in the form "{d 'yyyy-MM-dd'}".
        Parameters:
        d - The Date to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string
        See Also:
        http://incubator.apache.org/derby/docs/10.0/manuals/reference/sqlj230.html

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(java.sql.Time t)
        Escape a Time for use in an SQL query. The string returned is in the form "{t 'hh:mm:ss'}".
        Parameters:
        t - The Time to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string
        See Also:
        http://incubator.apache.org/derby/docs/10.0/manuals/reference/sqlj230.html

      • sqlEscape

        public static java.lang.String sqlEscape(java.sql.Timestamp ts)
        Escape a Timestamp for use in an SQL query. The string returned is in the form "{ts 'yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss.ffffffff'}".
        Parameters:
        ts - The Timestamp to be escaped
        Returns:
        The escaped string
        See Also:
        http://incubator.apache.org/derby/docs/10.0/manuals/reference/sqlj230.html

      • getString

        public static java.lang.String getString(java.sql.ResultSet rs,
                                         java.lang.String column)
                                  throws java.sql.SQLException
        ResultSets often come with "NULL" and return nulls, we preferr actual objects with appropriate values. Return a "" if result is null.
        Parameters:
        rs - The ResultSet to get this String column from
        column - The name of the column to get
        Returns:
        The target column value
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if column does not exist or other SQLExceptions

      • setModeGMT

        public static void setModeGMT()

      • date

        public static java.sql.Date date(int year,
                                 int month,
                                 int day)
        Create a SQL date from a year, month, day int. The SQL date comes from MS since 1970 but the "gregorianCalendar" Class likes to use MONTH based on 0=January. This does the right Thing so I wont forget later!
        Parameters:
        year - The year
        month - The month
        day - The day of month
        Returns:
        Date in sql form

      • date

        public static java.util.Date date(int year,
                                  int month,
                                  int day,
                                  int hr,
                                  int min,
                                  int sec)
        Create a Java date from a year, month, day, hr, min,sec . The SQL date comes from MS since 1970 but the "gregorianCalendar" Class likes to use MONTH based on 0=January. This does the right Thing so I wont forget later!
        Parameters:
        year - The year
        month - The month
        day - The day of month
        hr - The hour of day
        min - The minute
        sec - The second
        Returns:
        Date in sql form
